titleStmt.title: A fiery flying roll: a word from the Lord to all the great ones of the Earth, whom this may concerne: being the last warning piece at the dreadfull day of judgement. For now the Lord is come to 1 Informe 2 Advise and warne 3 Charge 4 Judge and sentence the great ones. As also most compassionately informing, and most lovingly and pathetically advising and warning London. With a terrible word and fatall blow from the Lord, upon the gathered churches. And all by his Most Excellent Majesty, dwelling in, and shining through Auxilium Patris, vu alias, Coppe. With another flying roll ensuing (to all the inhabitants of the Earth.) The contents of both following.
titleStmt.author: Coppe, Abiezer, 1619-1672.

fileDesc.extent: Approx. 48 KB of XML-encoded text transcribed from 12 1-bit group-IV TIFF page images.

availability.p: This keyboarded and encoded edition of the work described above is co-owned by the institutions providing financial support to the Early English Books Online Text Creation Partnership. This Phase I text is available for reuse, according to the terms of Creative Commons 0 1.0 Universal. The text can be copied, modified, distributed and performed, even for commercial purposes, all without asking permission.

titleStmt.title: A fiery flying roll: a word from the Lord to all the great ones of the Earth, whom this may concerne: being the last warning piece at the dreadfull day of judgement. For now the Lord is come to 1 Informe 2 Advise and warne 3 Charge 4 Judge and sentence the great ones. As also most compassionately informing, and most lovingly and pathetically advising and warning London. With a terrible word and fatall blow from the Lord, upon the gathered churches. And all by his Most Excellent Majesty, dwelling in, and shining through Auxilium Patris, vu alias, Coppe. With another flying roll ensuing (to all the inhabitants of the Earth.) titleStmt.author: Coppe, Abiezer, 1619-1672.

publicationStmt.publisher: in the beginning of that notable day, wherein the secrets of all hearts are laid open; and wherein the worst and foulest of villanies, are discovered, under the best and fairest outsides,

notesStmt.note: Reproduction of the original in the British Library.
The letters vu in the title, following "Auxilium Patris," are in Hebrew characters.

projectDesc.p: Created by converting TCP files to TEI P5 using tcp2tei.xsl, TEI @ Oxford.

editorialDecl.p: EEBO-TCP is a partnership between the Universities of Michigan and Oxford and the publisher ProQuest to create accurately transcribed and encoded texts based on the image sets published by ProQuest via their Early English Books Online (EEBO) database (http://eebo.chadwyck.com). The general aim of EEBO-TCP is to encode one copy (usually the first edition) of every monographic English-language title published between 1473 and 1700 available in EEBO.

EEBO-TCP aimed to produce large quantities of textual data within the usual project restraints of time and funding, and therefore chose to create diplomatic transcriptions (as opposed to critical editions) with light-touch, mainly structural encoding based on the Text Encoding Initiative (http://www.tei-c.org).

The EEBO-TCP project was divided into two phases. The 25,363 texts created during Phase 1 of the project have been released into the public domain as of 1 January 2015. Anyone can now take and use these texts for their own purposes, but we respectfully request that due credit and attribution is given to their original source.
Users should be aware of the process of creating the TCP texts, and therefore of any assumptions that can be made about the data.

Text selection was based on the New Cambridge Bibliography of English Literature (NCBEL). If an author (or for an anonymous work, the title) appears in NCBEL, then their works are eligible for inclusion. Selection was intended to range over a wide variety of subject areas, to reflect the true nature of the print record of the period. In general, first editions of a works in English were prioritized, although there are a number of works in other languages, notably Latin and Welsh, included and sometimes a second or later edition of a work was chosen if there was a compelling reason to do so.

Image sets were sent to external keying companies for transcription and basic encoding. Quality assurance was then carried out by editorial teams in Oxford and Michigan. 5% (or 5 pages, whichever is the greater) of each text was proofread for accuracy and those which did not meet QA standards were returned to the keyers to be redone. After proofreading, the encoding was enhanced and/or corrected and characters marked as illegible were corrected where possible up to a limit of 100 instances per text. Any remaining illegibles were encoded as <gap>s. Understanding these processes should make clear that, while the overall quality of TCP data is very good, some errors will remain and some readable characters will be marked as illegible. Users should bear in mind that in all likelihood such instances will never have been looked at by a TCP editor.
The texts were encoded and linked to page images in accordance with level 4 of the TEI in Libraries guidelines.

Copies of the texts have been issued variously as SGML (TCP schema; ASCII text with mnemonic sdata character entities); displayable XML (TCP schema; characters represented either as UTF-8 Unicode or text strings within braces); or lossless XML (TEI P5, characters represented either as UTF-8 Unicode or TEI g elements).
Keying and markup guidelines are available at the Text Creation Partnership web site.

2007-03 Mona LogarboText and markup reviewed and edited

div.p: A Fiery Flying Roll: A Word from the Lord to all the Great Ones of the Earth, whom this may concerne: Being the la≈øt WARNING PIECE at the dreadfull day of JUDGEMENT.

For now the LORD is come to
1 Informe the Great Ones.
2 Advi≈øe and warne the Great Ones.
3 Charge the Great Ones.
4 Judge and ≈øentence the Great Ones.
As al≈øo mo≈øt compa≈ø≈øionately informing, and mo≈øt lovingly and patheti ‚Ä¢ ally advi≈øing and warning London.
With a terrible Word and fatall Blow from the LORD, upon the Gathered CHURCHES.
And all by his Mo≈øt Excellent MAJESTY, dwelling in, and ≈øhining through AUXILIUM PATRIS, ◊£◊õ alias, Coppe..
With another FLYING ROLL en≈øuing (to all the Inhabitants of the Earth.) The Contents of both following.

q.p: The Lord of Ho≈øts (is) ≈øtaining the pride of all glory, and bringing into contempt all the honourable (per≈øons and things) of the Earth.

div.q: O London, London, how would I gather thee, as a hen gathereth her chickens under her wings, &c.

q.p: Know thou (in this thy day) the things that belong to thy Peace‚Äî
I know the bla≈øphemy of them which ≈øay they are Jewes, and are not, but are the Synagogue of Satan,

div.p: Imprinted at London, in the beginning of that notable day, wherein the ≈øecrets of all hearts are laid open; and wherein the wor≈øt and foule≈øt of villanies, are di≈øcovered, under the be≈øt and faire≈øt out≈øides. 1649.

div.head: THE PREFACE.
An inlet into the Land of Promi≈øe, the new Hieru≈øalem, and a gate into the en≈øuing Di≈øcour≈øe, worthy of ≈øerious con≈øideration.
div.p: My mo≈øt Excellent Maje≈øty (in me) hath ≈øtrangely and variou≈øly transformed this forme.
And behold, by mine owne Almightine≈ø≈øe (In me) I have been changed in a moment, in the twinkling of an eye, at the ≈øound of the Trump.
And now the Lord is d ‚Ä¢ ≈øcended from Heaven, with a ≈øhout, with the voyce of the Arch-angell, and with the Trump of God.

And the ≈øea, the earth, yea all things are now giving up their dead. And all things that ever were, are, or ≈øhall be vi≈øible‚Äîare the Grave wherein the King of Glory (the eternall, invi≈øible Almightine≈ø≈øe, hath lain as it were) dead and buried.

But behold, behold, he is now ri≈øen with a witne≈ø≈øe, to ≈øave Zion with vengeance, or to confound and plague all things into him≈øelf; who by his mighty Angell is proclaiming (with a loud voyce) That Sin and Tran≈øgre≈ø≈øion is fini≈øhed and ended; and everla≈øting righteou≈øne≈ø≈øe brought in; and the everla≈øting Go≈øpell preaching; Which everla≈øting Go≈øpell is brought in with mo≈øt terrible earth-quakes, and heaven-quakes, and with ≈øignes and wonders following. Amen.

And it hath plea≈øed my mo≈øt Excellent Maje≈øty, (who is univer≈øall love, and who≈øe ≈øervice is perfect freedome) to ≈øet this forme (the Writer of this Roll) as no ≈ømall ≈øigne and wonder in fle≈øhly I≈ørael; as you may partly ≈øee to the en≈øuing Di≈øcour≈øe.

And now (my deare ones!) every one under the Sun, I will onely point at the gate, thorow which I was led into that new City, new Hierulalem, and to the Spirits of ju≈øt men, made perfect‚ñ™ and to God the Judge of all.

Fir≈øt, all my ≈øtrength, my forces were utterly routed, my hou≈øe I dwelt in fired, my father and mother for≈øook me‚ñ™ the wife of my bo≈øome loathed me, mine old name was rotted, peri≈øhed; and I was utterly plagued, con≈øumed, damned, rammed, and ≈øunke into nothing, into the bowels of the ≈øtill Eternity (my mothers wombe) out of which I came naked, and whetherto I returned again naked‚ñ™ And lying a while there, rapt up in ≈øilence, at length (the body or outward forme being aw ‚Ä¢ ke ‚Ä¢ ll this while) I heard with my outward eare (to my apprehen≈øion) a mo≈øt terrible thunder-clap, and after that a‚ñ™ ≈øecond. And upon the ≈øecond thunder-clap, which was exceeding terrible, I ≈øaw a great body of light, like the light of the Sun, and red as fire, in the forme of a drum (as it were) whereupon with exceeding trembling and amazement on the fle≈øh, and with joy un≈øpe ‚Ä¢ k ‚Ä¢ ble in the ≈øpirit, I clapt my hands, and cryed out, Amen, Halelujah, Halelujah, Amen. And ≈øo lay trembling, ≈øweating, and ≈ømoaking (for the ≈øpace of half an houre) at length with a loud voyce (I inwardly) cryed out, Lord, what wilt thou do with me; my mo≈øt excellent maje≈øty and eternall glory (in me) an≈øwered & ≈øayd‚ñ™ Fear not, I will take thee up into mine everla≈øting Kingdom. But thou ≈øhalt (fir≈øt) drink
a bitter cup, a bitter cup, a bitter cup; wherupon (being filled with exceeding amazement) I was throwne into the belly of hell (and take what you can of it in the≈øe expre≈ø≈øions, though the matter is beyond expre≈ø≈øion) I was among all the Devils in hell, even in their mo≈øt hideous how.

And under all this terrour, and amazement, there was a little ≈øpark of tran≈øcendent, tran≈øplendent, un≈øpeakable glory, which ‚Ä¢ urvived, and ≈øu≈øtained it ≈øelf, triumphing, exulting, and exalting it ≈øelf above all the Fiends. And confounding the very blackne≈ø≈øe of darkne≈ø≈øe (you mu≈øt take it in the≈øe tearmes, for it is infinitely beyond expre≈ø≈øion.) Vpon this the life was taken out of the body (for a ≈øea≈øon) and it was thus re≈øembled, as if a man with a great bru≈øh dipt in whiting, ≈øhould with one ≈øtroke w ‚Ä¢ pe out, or ≈øweep off a picture upon a wall, &c. after a while, breath and life was recurned into the form againe; whereupon I ≈øaw various ≈øtreames of light (in the night) which appeared to the outward eye; and immediately I ≈øaw three hearts (or three appearances) in the form of hearts, of exceeding brightne≈ø≈øe; and immediately an innumerable company of hearts, filling each corner of the room where I was. And me thoughts there was variety and di≈øtinction, as if there had been ≈øeverall hearts, and yet mo≈øt ≈øtrangely and unexpre≈ø≈øibly complicated or folded up in unity. I clearely ≈øaw di≈øtinction, diver≈øity, variety, and as clearly ≈øaw all ≈øwallowed up into unity. And it hath been my ≈øong many times ≈øince, within and without, unity, univer≈øality, univer≈øality, unity, Eternall Maje≈øty, &c. And at this vi≈øion, a mo≈øt ≈øtrong, glorious voyce uttered the≈øe words, The ≈øpirits of ju≈øt men made perfect‚ñ™ the ≈øpirits &c, with whom I had as ab≈øolut, cleare, full communion, and in a two fold more familiar
way, then ever I had outwardly with my deare≈øt friends, and neare≈øt relations. The vi≈øions and revelations of God, and the ≈øtrong hand of eternall invi≈øible almightine≈ø≈øe, was ≈øtretched out upon me, within me, for the ≈øpace of foure dayes and nights, without intermi≈ø≈øion.

The time would faile if I would tell you all, but it is not the good will and plea≈øure of my mo≈øt excellent Maje≈øty in me, to declare any more (as yet) then thus m ‚Ä¢ ch further: That among≈øt tho≈øe various voyces that were then uttered within, the≈øe were ≈øome, Blood, blood, Where, where? upon the hypocriticall holy heart, &c. Another thus, Vengeance, vengeance, vengeance, Plagues, plagues, upon the Inhabitants of the earth; Fire, fire, fire, Sword, ≈øword, &c. upon all that bow not down to eternall Maje≈øty, univer≈øall love; I'le recover, recover, my wooll, my flax, my money. Declare, declare, feare thou not the faces of any; I am (in thee) a munition of Rocks, &c.

Go up to London, It not being ≈øhewen to me, what I ≈øhould do, more then preach and print ≈øomething, &c. very little expecting I ≈øhould be ≈øo ≈øtrangely acted, as to (my exceeding joy and delight) I have been, though to the utter cracking of my credit, and to the rotting of my old name which is damned, and ca≈øt out (as a toad to the dunghill) that I might have a new name, with me, upon me, within me, which is, Iam‚Äî to London, that great City, write, write, write. And behold I writ, and lo a hand was ≈øent to me, and a roll of a book was therein, which this fle≈øhly hand would have put wings to, before the time. Whereupon it was ≈ønatcht out of my hand, & the Roll thru≈øt into my mouth; and I eat it up, and filled my bowels with it, (Eze. 2. 8. &c. cha. 3. 1, 2, 3.) where it was as bitter as worm-wood; and it lay broiling, and burning in my ≈øtomack, till I brought it forth in this forme.
And now I ≈øend it flying to thee, with my heart, And all

list.item: CHAP. 1. SEverall ≈øtrange, yet true and ≈øea≈øonable informations to the great ones, as al≈øo an apologeticall hint of the Authors principle, &c.
CHAP. 2. Severall new, ≈øtrange, yet ≈øea≈øonable and good advice, and whol≈øome admonitions, and the la≈øt warning to the great ones, as from the Lord.
CHAP. 3. Severall di≈ømall, dolefull cryes, & out-crieo, which pierce the eares and heart of his excellent Maje≈øty, & how the King of Kings, the King of heaven charges the great ones of the earth.

CHAP. 4. How the Judge of heaven and earth, who judgeth righteous‚ñ™ judgment, pa≈ø≈øeth ≈øentence again≈øt all tho≈øe great ones, who like ≈øturdy O akes & tall Cedars wil not bow, and how hee intends to breake them, and blow them up by the roots‚ñ™
CHAP. 5. A mo≈øt compa≈ø≈øionate information, and a mo≈øt loving & patheticall warning and advice to London.
CHAP. 6. A terrible word and fatall blow from the Lord upon the gathered Churches, who pretend mo≈øt for God, yet defie the Almighty more then the vile≈øt.

CHAP. 1. The Authors commi≈ø≈øion to write. A terrible woe denounced again≈øt tho≈øe that flight the roll. The Lords claim to all things; Together with a hint of a two-fold recovery, where through the mo≈øt hypocriticall heart ≈øhall be ripped up, &c.

CHAP. 2. How the Lord will recover his outward things (things of this life) as money, corn, wool, flax, &c. and for whom: And how they ≈øhal be plagned that detaine them as their owne. Wherein al≈øo are ≈øome mi≈øtical hints concerning St. Michaels day, and the Lords day following it this yeare; as al≈øo of the dominicall letter D, &c.

CHAP. 3. A ≈øtrange, yet mo≈øt true ≈øtorie, vnder which is couch ‚Ä¢ d that lion, who≈øe roaring ≈øhall make all the bea≈øts of the field to tremble, and all the kingdomes of the world quake. Wherein al≈øo (in part) the ≈øubtility of the welfavour'd harlot is di≈øcovered, and her fle≈øh burnt with that fire which ≈øhall burn down all Churches, except that of the fir≈øt borne, &c.

CHAP. 4. That the Author hath been ≈øet as a ≈øign and wonder, &c. as well as most of the Prophets formerly; as al≈øo what ≈øtrange po≈øturs that divine Majestie (that dwels in his forme) hath ≈øet the'forme in: with the mo≈øt ≈øtrange and varions effects thereof
upon the ≈øpectators. His communion with the ≈øpirits of ju≈øt men made perfect, and with God the judg of all hinted at.

CHAP. 5. The Authors ≈øtrange and lofty carriage towards great ones, & his mo≈øt lowly carriage towards beggars, rogues, pri≈øoners, gyp≈øies, &c. Together with a large Declaration what glory ≈øhall ari≈øe up from under all the≈øe a≈øhes. The mo≈øt ≈øtrange & mo≈øt ≈øecret and terrible, yet mo≈øt glorious de≈øigne of God, in choo≈øing ba≈øe things, to confound‚ñ™ things that are: And how, A mo≈øt terrible viall poured out upon the well-favoured harlot; and how the Lord is bringing into contempt not only honourable per≈øons (with a vengeance) but all honourable holy things al≈øo. Whol≈øome advice, with a terrible threat to the Formali≈øts: And how BASE things have confounded ba≈øe things: And how ba≈øe things have been a fiery chariot to mount the Author up into divine glory and un≈øpeakable Maje≈øtie: And how his wife is, & his life is in that beauty, which maketh vi≈øible beauty ≈øeem meere deformity.

CHAP. 6. Great ones mu≈øt bow to the poore≈øt pea≈øants, or el≈øe they ≈øhall rue for it; No material ≈øword or humane power (what≈øoever) but the pure ≈øpirit of univer≈øall love, who is the eternall God, can breake the necke of tyranny, oppr ‚Ä¢ ≈ø≈øion, and abhominable pride and cruell murther, &c. A catologue of ≈øeverall judgments recited, as ≈øo many warning-pieces to approp ‚Ä¢ iators, impropriators, and ant ‚Ä¢
‚ñ™free communicants.

CHAP. 7. A further di≈øcovery of the ≈øubtilty of the well favoured harlot, with a parley between her and the ≈øpirit. As al≈øo the hor ‚Ä¢ id villany that l ‚Ä¢ es hid under her ≈ømooth words, and ≈øweet tongue (in pleading again≈øt the letter and hi≈øtory, and for the ≈øpirit and mi≈øtery, and all for her own ends) detected. Al≈øo upon what account the ≈øpirit is put, and upon what account the letter, &c. And what the true communion, and what the true breaking of bread is.

CHAP. 8. The wel-favoured harlots cloaths ≈øtript off, her nakedne≈ø≈øe di≈øcovered, her no≈øe ≈ølit. Her ‚Ä¢ unting after the young man void of under≈øtanding, from corner to corner, from religion to religion: And the ≈øpirit pur≈øuing, overtaking, and de≈øtroying her, &c. With a terrible thunder-clap i'th clo≈øe.

div.head: A word from the Lord to all the Great Ones of the Earth (whom this may concerne) being the la≈øt Warning Piece, &c.

argument.p: 1 The word of the Lord came expre≈øly to me, ≈øaying, Sonne of man write a Roule, and the≈øe words, from my mouth, to the Great ones, ≈øaying, thus ≈øaith the Lord:
Slight not this Roule, neither laugh at it, lea≈øt I ≈ølight you, and cau≈øe all men to ≈ølight and ≈øcorne you; lea≈øt I de≈øtroy you, and laugh at your de≈øtruction, &c.
2 This is, (and with a witne≈ø≈øe, ≈øome of you ≈øhall finde it, to be) an edg'd toole; and there's no je≈øting with it, or laughing at it.
No ≈øleepy Dormou≈øe ≈øhall dare to creep up the edge of it.
Thus ≈øaith the Lord, You ≈øhall finde with a witne≈ø≈øe, that I am now comming to

list.item: 1 Informe you, O ye great ones.
2 Advi≈øe and warne you, O ye great ones.
3 Charge you, O ye great ones.
4 Judge and ≈øentence you, O ye great ones.

div.head: CHAP. I. Containing ≈øeverall ≈øtrange, yet true and ≈øea≈øonable Informations, to the great ones. As al≈øo an apologeticall hint, of the Authors Principle, ≈øtanding in the front.‚Äî
div.p: 1. THus ≈øaith the Lord, I inform you, that I overturn, overturn, overturn. And as the Bi≈øhops, Charles, and the Lords, have had their turn, overturn, ≈øo your turn ≈øhall be next (ye ≈øurviving great ones) by what Name or Title ≈øoever dignified or di≈øtingui≈øhed) who ever you are, that oppo≈øe me, the Eternall God, who am UNIVERSALL Love, and who≈øe ≈øervice is perfect freedome, and pure Libertini≈øme.

2 An Apologeticall hint concerning the Authors Principle, the re ‚Ä¢ ult‚Äîis negative; hee ≈øpeaks little in the affirmative becau≈øe not one in a hundred, yea even of his former acqu ‚Ä¢ intance, now know him, neither mu≈øt they yet. But afore I proceed any further, be it known to you, That although that excellent Maje≈øty, which dwels in the Writer of this Roule, hath reconciled ALL THINGS to him≈øelfe, yet this hand (which now writes) never drew ≈øword, or ≈øhed one drop of any mans blood. [I am free from the blood of all men] though (I ≈øay) all things are reconciled to me, the eternall God (IN HIM) yet ≈øword levelling, or digging-levelling, are neither of them his principle.

Both are as farre from his principle, as the Ea≈øt is from the We≈øt, or the Heavens from the Earth, (though, I ≈øay, reconciled to both, as to all things el≈øe) and though he hath more ju≈øtice, righteou≈øne≈ø≈øe, truth, and ≈øincerity, ≈øhining in tho≈øe low dunghils, (as they are e≈øteemed) then in the Sunne, Moone, and all the Stars.

3 I come not forth (in him) either with materiall ≈øword, or Mattock, but now (in this my day‚Äî) I make him my Swordbearer, to brandi≈øh the Sword of the Spirit, as he hath done ≈øeverall dayes and nights together, thorow the ≈øtreets of the great City.
4 And now thus ≈øaith the Lord:

Though you can as little endure the word LEVELLING, as could the lat-≈ølaine or dead Charles (your foretunner, who is gone before you‚Äî) and had as live heare the Devill named, as heare of the Levellers (M ‚Ä¢ n-Levellers) which is, and who (indeed) are but ≈øhadowes of mo≈øt terrible, yet great and glorious good things to come.

5 Behold, behold, behold, I the eternall God, the Lord of Ho≈øts‚ñ™ who am that mighty Leveller, am comming (yea even at the doores) to Levell in good earne≈øt, to Levell to ≈øome purpo≈øe, to Levell with a witne≈ø≈øe, to Levell the Hills with the Valleyes, and to lay the Mountaines low.

6 High Mountaines! lofty Cedars! its high time for you to enter into the Rocks, and to hide you in the du≈øt, for feare of the Lord, and for the glory of his Maje≈øty. For the lofty looks of man ≈øhall be humbled, and the haughtine≈ø≈øe of men ≈øhall be bowed downe, and the Lord ALONE ≈øhall be exalted in that day; For the day of the Lord of Hoa≈øts, ≈øhall be upon every one that is proud, and lofty, and upon every one that is lifted up, and he ≈øhall be brought low. And upon all the Cedars of Lebanon, that
are high and lifted up, and upon all the Oaks of Ba≈øhan; and upon all the high Mountaines; and upon all the Hils that are lifted up, and upon every high Tower‚ñ™ and upon every fenced Wall; and upon all the Ships of Tar≈øhi≈øh, and upon all plea≈øant Pictures.
And the LOFTINESSE of man ≈øhall be bowed down, and the haughtine≈ø≈øe of men ≈øhall be laid low. And the Lord ALONE ≈øhall be exalted in that day, and the Idols he ≈øhall utterly aboli≈øh.
And they ≈øhall go into the holes of the Rocks, and into the Caves of the Earth, for ≈øcare of the Lord, and for the glory of his Maje≈øty, when he ari≈øeth to ≈øhake terribly the earth.

In that day a man ≈øhall ca≈øt his Idols of Silver, and Idols of Gold‚Äîto the bats, and to the Moles. To go into the Clefts of the Rocks and into the tops of the ragged Rocks, for feare of the Lord, and for the glory of his Maje≈øty. For the Lord is now RISEN to ≈øhake terribly the Earth, I≈øa. 2. 10. to the end of the Chapter.
7 Hill! Mountains! Cedars! Mighty men! Your breath is in your no≈øtrils.
Tho≈øe that have admired, adored, idolized, magnified, ≈øet you up, fought for you, ven ‚Ä¢ ured goods, and good name; limbe and life for you, ≈øhall cea≈øe from you.

You ≈øhall not (at all be accounted of (not one of you) ye ≈øturdy Oake) who bowe not downe before eternall Maje≈øty: Vniver≈øall Love, who≈øe ≈øervice is perfect freedome, and who hath put down the mighty (remember, remember your fore-runner) and who is putting down the mighty from their ≈øeats; and exalting them of low degree.
8 Oh let not, (for your owne ≈øakes) let not the mother of Harlots in you, who is very ≈øubtle of heart.

Nor the Bea≈øt (without you) what do you call 'em? The Mini≈øters, fat par≈øons, Vica ‚Ä¢ s, Lecturers, &c. who (for their owne ba≈øe ends, to maintaine their pride, and pompe, and to fill their owne paunche ‚Ä¢ , and pur≈øes) have been the chiefe in≈øtruments of all tho≈øe horrid abominations, helli≈øh, cruell, devilli≈øh p ‚Ä¢ r≈øecutions, in this Nation which cry for vengeance. For your owne ≈øakes (I ≈øay) let neither the one, nor the other bewitch you, or charme your eares, to heare them ≈øay, the≈øe things ≈øhall not befall
you, the≈øe Scriptures ≈øhall not be fulfilled upon you, but upon the Pope, Turke, and Heathen Princes, &c.
9 Or if any of them ≈øhould (through ≈øubtilty for their owne ba≈øe ends) creep into the My≈øtery of that forementioned I≈øay 2‚ñ™ Scripture.
And tell you, Tho≈øe words are to be taken in the My≈øtery only; and they onely point out a ≈øpirituall, inward levelling (once more, for your owne ≈øakes, I ≈øay) believe them not.

10 'Tis true, the Hi≈øtory, or Letter, (I ≈øpeake comparatively) is but as it were haire-cloth; the My≈øtery is fine Flax. My flax, ≈øaith the Lord, and the Thief and the Robber will ≈øteale from me my flax, to cover his nakedne≈ø≈øe, that his filthine≈ø≈øe may not appeare.
But behold, I am (now) recovering my flax out of his hand, and di≈øcovering his lewdne≈ø≈øe‚Äîverbum ≈øat‚Äî
11 'Tis true, the My≈øtery is my joy, my delight, my life.
And the Prime levelling, is laying low the Mountaines, and levelling the Hils in man.
But this is not all.

For lo I come (≈øaith the Lord) with a vengeance, to levell al≈øo your Honour, Riches, &c. to ≈øtaine the pride of all your glory, and to bring into contempt all the Honourable (both per≈øons and things) upon the earth, I≈øa. 23. 9.

12 For this Honour, Nobility, Gentility, Propriety, Superfluity, &c. hath (without contradiction) been the Father of helli≈øh horrid pride, arrogance, haughtine≈ø≈øe, loftine≈ø≈øe, murder, malice, of all manner of wickedne≈ø≈øe and implety; yea the cau≈øe of all the blood that ever hath been ≈øhed, from the blood of righteous Abell, to the blood of the last-Levellers that were ≈øhot to death. And now (as I live ≈øaith the Lord) I am come to make inqui≈øition for blood; for murder and pride, &c.

13 I ≈øee the root of it all The Axe is laid to the root of the Tree (by the Eternall God, My Self, ≈øaith the Lord) I will hew „Äà‚óä„Äâ down. And as I live, I will plague your Honour, Pompe, Greatne≈ø≈øe, Superfluity, and confound it into parity, equality, community; that the neck of horrid pride, murder, malice, and tyranny, &c. may be chopt off at one blow. And that my ≈øelfe, the Eternall God, who am Vniver≈øall Love, may fill the Earth with univer≈øall love, univer≈øall peace, and perfect freedome; which
can never be by humane ≈øword or ≈øtrength accompli≈øhed.
14 Wherefore bow downe, bow downe, you ≈øturdy Oakes, and tall Cedars; bow, or by my ≈øelf Ile break you.
Ile cau≈øe ≈øome of you (on whom I have compa≈ø≈øion) to bow &c. and will terribly plague the re≈øt.
My little finger ≈øhall be heavier on them, then my whole loynes were on Pharaoh of old.
15 And maugre the ≈øubtilty, and ≈øedulity, the craft and cruelty of hell, and earth: this Levelling ≈øhall up.

Not by ≈øword; we (holily) ≈øcorne to fight for any thing; we had as live be dead drunk every day of the weeke, and lye with whores i'th market place, and account the≈øe as good actions as taking the poore abu≈øed, en≈ølaved ploughmans money from him (who is almo≈øt every where undone, and ≈øqueezed to death; and not ≈øo much as that plaguy, un≈øupportable, helli≈øh burden, and oppre≈ø≈øion, of Tythes taken off his ≈øhoulders, notwith≈øtanding all his hone≈øty, fidelity, Taxes, Freequarter, petitioning &c. for the ≈øame,) we had rather ≈øtarve, I ≈øay, then take away his money from him, for killing of men.

Nay, if we might have Captains pay, and a good fat Par≈øonage or two be≈øides, we would ≈øcorne to be ≈øword≈ømen, or fight with tho≈øe (mo≈øtly) carnall weapons, for any thing, or again≈øt any one, or for our livings.
16 No, no, wee'l live in de≈øpite of our foes; and this levelling (to thy torment, O mighty man) ≈øhall up, not by ≈øword, not by might, &c. but by my Spirit, ≈øaith the Lord.
For I am ri≈øen, for I am ri≈øen, for I am ri≈øen, to ≈øhake terribly the earth, and not the earth onely, but the heavens al≈øo, &c.
But here I ≈øhall cea≈øe informing you.
You may for your further information (if you plea≈øe) reade my Roule to all the rich Inhabitants of the earth.
Reade it if you be wi≈øe, I ≈øhall now advice you.

div.head: CHAP. II. Containing ≈øeverall new, ≈øtrange, yet ≈øea≈øonable Admonitions, and good advice; as the la≈øt warning to the Great Ones of the Earth. from the Lord.
div.p: 1 THus ≈øaith the Lord: B: Ser√≤ ≈øapiunt P ‚Ä¢ ryges, ≈øed nunquam Sera e≈øt ad Bonos mores via, 1 Admonition to great ones. wi≈øe now therefore, O ye Rulers, &c. Be in≈øtructed, &c. Ki≈ø≈øe the Sunne, &c. Yea, ki≈ø≈øe Beggers, Pri≈øoners, warme them, feed them, cloathe them, money them, relieve them, relea≈øe them, take them into your hou≈øes, don't ≈øerve them as dogs, without doore. &c.
Owne them, they are fle≈øh of your fle≈øh, your owne brothren, your owne Si≈øters, every whit as good (and if I ≈øhould ≈øtand in competition with you) in ≈øome degrees better then your ≈øelves.
2 Once more, I ≈øay, own them; they are your ≈øelf, make them one with you, or el ‚Ä¢ e go howling into hell; bowle for the mi≈øeries that are comming upon you, ≈øowle.

The very ≈øhadow of levelling ≈øword-levelling, man-levelling, frighted you, (and who, li ‚Ä¢ e your ≈øelves, can blame you, becau≈øe it ≈øhook your Kingdome?) but now the ≈øub≈øtantiality of levelling is coming.
The Eternall God, the mighty Leveller is comming, yea come, even at the door; and what will you do in that day.
Repent, repent, repent, Bow down, bow down, bow, or howle, refigne, or be damned; Bow downe, bow downe, you ≈øtu ‚Ä¢ dy Oakes, and Cedars, bow downe.

Veile too, and ki≈ø≈øe the meaner ≈øhru ‚Ä¢ s. Bow, or el≈øe (by my ≈øelf ≈øaith the Lord) Ile breake you in pieces (≈øome of you) others I will teare up by the roots; I will ≈øuddenly deale with you all, ≈øome in one way; ≈øome in another. Wherefore

lg.l: Eall down before him, ki≈ø≈øe him in the ≈øtreet.

div.p: Once more, he is thy brother, thy fellow, fle≈øh of thy fle≈øh.
Turne not away thi ‚Ä¢ e eyes from thine own‚ñ™ FLESH, lea≈øt I pull out thine eyes and throw thee headlong into hell.

3 Mine eares are fill ‚Ä¢ d brim full with cryes of poore pri≈øoners, Newgate, Ludgate cryes (of late) are ≈øeldome out of mine eares.
Tho≈øe dolefull cryes, Bread, bread, bread for the Lords ≈øake, pierce mine eares, and heart, I can no longer for ‚Ä¢ eare.
Werefore high you apace to all pri≈øons in the Kingdome,2 Admonition to great ones.
4 Bow before tho≈øe poore, na≈øty, lou≈øie, ragged wretches, ≈øay to them, your humble ≈øervants, Sirs‚ñ™ (without a complement) we let you go free, and ≈øerve you, &c.
Do this (or as I live ≈øaith the Lord) thine eyes (at lea≈øt) ≈øhall be boared out, and thou carried captive into a ≈øtrange Land.

5 Give over, give over, thy od ‚Ä¢ ous, na≈øty, abominable fa≈øting,3 Admonition to great ones for ≈øtrife and debate, and to ≈ømite with the fi≈øt of wickedne≈ø≈øe. And in≈øtead thereof, loo≈øe the bands of wickedne≈ø≈øe, undo the heavy burdens, let the oppre≈ø≈øed go free, and breake every yoake. Deale thy bread to the hungry, and bring the poore that are ca≈øt out (both of hou≈øes and Synagogues) to thy hou≈øe. Cover the raked: Hide not thy ≈øelf from thine owne fle≈øh, from a creeple, a rogue, a begg ‚Ä¢ r, he's thine owne fle≈øh. From a Whoremong ‚Ä¢ r, a thief, &c. he's fle≈øh of thy fle≈øh, and his theft, and wheredome is fle≈øh of thy fle≈øh al≈øo, thine owne fle≈øh. Thou mai≈øt have ten, times more of each within thee, then he that acts outwardly in either, Remember, turn not away thine eyes from thine OWN FLESH.
6 Give over, give over thy midnight mi≈øchief.4 Admonition to great ones
Let branding with the letter B‚ñ™ alone.
Be no longer ≈øo horridly, helli≈øhly, impudently, arrogantly, wicked‚ñ™ as to judge what is ≈øinne, what not, what evill, and what not, what bla ‚Ä¢ phemy, and what not.
For thou and all thy reverend Divines, ≈øo called (who Divine for Tythes, hire, and money, and ≈øerve the Lord Je≈øus Chri≈øt for their owne bellyes) are ignorant of this one thing.
7 That ≈øinne and tran≈øgre≈ø≈øion is fini≈øht, its a meere riddle, that they, with all their humane learning can never reade.
Neither can they under≈øtand what pure honour is wrapt up in the Kings Motto, Honi Soit qui Mal. y. Pen≈øe. Evill to him that evill thinks.
Some there are (who are accounted the off ≈øcouring of all things) who are Noble Knights of the Garter. Since which‚Äîthey could ≈øee no evill, thinke no evill, doe no evill, know no evill.
ALL is Religion that they ≈øpeak, and honour that they do.

But all you that eat of the Tree of Knowledge of Good and Evill, and have not your Evill eye Pickt out, you call Good Evill, and Evill Good; Light Darkne≈ø≈øe, and Darkne≈ø≈øe Light; Truth Bla≈øphemy, and Bla≈øphemy Truth.
And you are at this time of your Father the Devill, and of your brother the Phari≈øee, who ≈øtill ≈øay of Chri≈øt (who is now alive) ≈øay we not well that he hath a Devill.
9 Take heed, take heed, take heed.
Filthy blinde Sodomites called Angels men, they ≈øeeing no further then the formes of men.

10 There are Angels (now) come downe from Heaven, in the ≈øhapes and formes of men, who are full of the vengeance of the Lord; and are to poure out the plagues of God upon the Earth, and to torment the Inhabitants thereof.
Some of the≈øe Angels I have been acquainted withall.

And I have looked upon them as Devils, accounting them Devils incarnate, and have run from place to place, to hide my ≈øelf from them, ≈øhunning their company; and have been utterly a≈øhamed when I have been ≈øeen with them.

But for my labour; I have been plagued and tormented beyond expre≈ø≈øion. So that now I had rather behold one of the≈øe Angels Rev. 15, Judges 5, Revel. 10, Neh. 13. 25, pouring out the plagues of God, cur≈øing; and teaching others to cur≈øe bitterly.

And had rather heare a mighty Angell (in man) ≈øwearing a full-mouthd Oath; and ≈øee the ≈øpirit of Nehemiah (in any form of man, or woman) running upon an uncleane Jew (a pretended Saint) and tearing the haire of his head like a mad man, cur≈øing, and making others fall a ≈øwearing, then heare a zealous Presbyterian, Independent, or This will come in reque≈øt with you next; you may remember that Independency, which is now ≈øo hug'd, was counted bla≈øphemy, and bani≈øhment was too good for it. ≈øpirituall Notioni≈øt, pray, preach, or exerci≈ø ‚Ä¢ .

11 Well‚ñ™! To the pure all things are pure. God hath ≈øo cleared cur≈øing, ≈øwearing, in ≈øome, that that which goes for ≈øwearing and cur≈øing in them, is more glorious then praying and preaching in others.
And what God hath clean≈øed, call not thou uncleane.

And if Peter prove a great tran≈øgre≈ø≈øor of the Law, by doing that which was as odious as killing a man; if he at length (though he be loath at fir≈øt) eat that which was common and unclean &c. (I give but a hint) blame him not, much le≈ø≈øe lift up a finger
again≈øt, or plant a helli≈øh Ordinance‚Äîagain≈øt him, lea≈øt thou be plagu ‚Ä¢ d, and damned too, for thy zeale, blinde Religion, and fle≈øhly holine≈ø≈øe, which now ≈øtinks above ground, though formerly it had a good ≈øavour,

12 But O thou holy, zealous, devout, righteous, religious on ‚Ä¢ (whoever thou art) that ≈øee≈øt evill, or any thing uncleane; do thou ≈øweare, if thou dare≈øt, if it be but (l'faith) I'le throw thee to Hell for it (≈øaith the Lord) and laugh at thy de≈øtruction.
While Angels (in the forme of men) ≈øhall ≈øweare, Heart, Blood, Wounds, and by the Eternall God, &c. in profound purity, and in high Honour, and Maje≈øty.
13 Well! one hint more; there's ≈øwearing ignorantly, i'th darke, vainely, and there's ≈øwearing i'th light, gloriou≈øly.
Well! man of the earth! Lord E≈øau! what ha≈øt thou to do with tho≈øe who ≈øweare upon the former account?

Vengeance is mine, Judgement, Hell, Wrath, &c. all is mine (≈øaith the Lord) dare not thou to ≈øet thy foot ≈øo impudently and arrogantly upon one ≈øtep of my Throne: I am Judge my ≈øelf‚ÄîBe wi≈øe, give over, have done‚Äî

14 And as for the latter ≈øort of ≈øwearing, thou knowe≈øt it not when thou heare≈øt it. It's no new thing for thee to call Chri≈øt Beel-zebub, and Beel-zebub Chri≈øt; to call a holy Angell a Devill, and a Devill an Angell.

15 I charge thee (in the name of the Eternall God) meddle not with either, let the Tares alone, lea≈øt thou pull up the Wheat al≈øo, woe be to thee if thou do≈øt. Let both alone (I ≈øay) lea≈øt thou ≈øhoulde≈øt happen of a holy ≈øwearing Angell; and take a Lion by the paw to thine owne de≈øtruction.
‚ÄîNever was there ≈øuch a time ≈øince the world ≈øtood, as now is.
Thou knowe≈øt not the ≈øtrange appearances of the Lord, now a daies. Take heed, know thou ha≈øt been warned.
16 And whatever thou do≈øt, dip not thy little finger in blood5 Admonition to great ones any more, thou art up to the elbowes already: Much ≈øope, yea much nitre cannot clean≈øe thee, &c.
Much more have I to ≈øay to thee (≈øaith the Lord) but I will do it ≈øecretly; and dart a quiver full of arrowes into thy h ‚Ä¢ art; and I will now charge thee.

div.head: CHAP. III. Containing ≈øeverall di≈ømall, dolefull cryes, and outcries. which pierce the eares and heart of his Excellent Maje≈øty, the King of Kings. And how the King of Heaven chargeth the Great Ones of the Earth.
div.p: 1 THus ≈øaith the Lord, Be ≈øilent, O all fle≈øh, before the Lord; be ≈øilent; O lofty, haughty, great ones of the Earth.
There are ≈øo many Bils of Indictment preferred again≈øt thee, that both heaven and earth blu≈øh thereat.

How long ≈øhall I heare the ≈øighs and groanes, and ≈øee the teares of poore widowes; and heare cur≈øes in every corner; and all ≈øorts of people crying out oppre≈ø≈øion, oppre≈ø≈øion, tyranny, tyranny, the wor≈øt of tyranny, unheard of, unna ‚Ä¢ urall tyranny.
‚ÄîO my back, my ≈øhoulders. O Tythes, Excize, Taxes, Pollings, &c. O Lord! O Lord God Almighty!
What, a little finger heavier then former loynes?
What have I engaged my goods, my life, &c. for≈øooke my deare≈øt relations, and all for liberty and true freedome, for freedome from oppre≈ø≈øion, and more laid on my back, &c.
2 Mine eares are filled brim full with confu≈øed noi≈øe, cries, and outcries; O the innumerable complaints and groanes that pierce my heart (thorow and thorow) O a≈øtoni≈øhing complaints.

Was ever the like ingratitude heard of ≈øince the world ≈øtood? what! be≈øt friends, ≈øure≈øt friends, ≈ølighted, ≈øcorned, and that which cometh from them (in the ba≈øe≈øt manner) contemned, and ≈øome rewarded with pri≈øons, ≈øome with death?
O the abominable per≈øidiou≈øne≈ø≈øe, fal≈øeheartedne≈ø≈øe; ≈øelf-≈øeeking, ≈øelf-inriching, and Kingdome-depopulating, and deva≈øtating, &c.
The≈øe, and divers of the ≈øame nature, are the cries of England.
And can I any longer for beare?
I have heard, I have heard, the groaning of my people. And now I come to deliver them, ≈øaith the Lord.
Woe be to Pharaoh King of Egypt.
You Great Ones that are not tackt nor tainted, you may laugh and ≈øing, whom this hitteth it hitteth. And it ≈øhall hit home.
And this which followeth, all whom it concerneth, by what name or title ≈øoever dignified or di≈øtingui≈øhed.

3 You mo≈øtly hate tho≈øe (called Levellers) who (for ought you know) acted as they did, out of the ≈øincerity, ≈øimplicity, and fidelity of their hearts; fearing lea≈øt they ≈øhould come under the notion of Covenant-breakers, if they did not ≈øo act.
Which if ≈øo, then were they mo≈øt barbarou≈øly, unnaturally, belli≈øhly murdered; and they died Martyrs for God and their Countrey.
And their blood cries vengeance, vengeance, in mine ears, ≈øaith the Lord.

4 Well! let it be how it will; the≈øe Once more know, that Sword-leveling is not my principle; I onely pronounce the righteous judgements of the Lord upon Earth, as I dur≈øt. Levellers (≈øo called) you mo≈øtly hated, though in outward declarations you owned their Tenents as your owne Principle.

So you mo≈øtly hate me (≈øaith the Lord) though in outward declarations you profe≈ø≈øe me, and ≈øeeme to owne me, more then a thou≈øand whom you de≈øpi≈øe, and account wor≈øe than your ≈øelves, who are neerer the Kingdome of Heaven then your ≈øelve.

You have killed Levellers (≈øo called) you al≈øo (with wicked hands) have ≈ølain me the Lord of life, who am now ri≈øen, and ri≈øen indeed, (and you ≈øhall know, and feele it with a witne≈ø≈øe) to Levell you in good earne≈øt. And to lay low all high hils, and every mountaine that is high, and lifted up, &c.
5 Well! once more, read Jam. 5, 1. to 7‚ÄîYe have killed the ju≈øt‚ÄîYe have killed, ye have killed, ye have killed the ju≈øt.
The blood cryeth in mine eares, Vengeance, vengeance, vengeance, vengeance is mine, I will recompence.
Well! what will you do with Bray, and the poore pri≈øoners el≈øewhere? You know not what you do.
You little know what will become of you.
One of you had be≈øt remember your dream about your Fathers Moule‚Äî

6 Neither do I forget the one hundred ≈øpent in ≈øuper≈øluous di≈øhes (at your late great London Fea≈øt, for I know what‚Äî)
when hundreds of poore wretches dyed with hunger‚ñ™
I have heard a ≈øound in mine eares, that no le≈ø≈øe then a hundred died in one week, pined, and ≈øtarved with hunger.
Howle you great ones, for all that fea≈øt daies dole, &c. heare your doome.

div.head: CHAP. IV. How the Judge of Heaven and Earth, who judgeth righteous judgement, pa≈ø≈øeth ≈øentence again≈øt all tho≈øe Great Ones, who (like Oakes and tall Cedars) will not bow. And how he intends to blow them up by the roots.
div.p: 1 THus ≈øaith the Lord: All you tall Cedars, and ≈øturdy Oakes, who bow not down, who bow not down‚ÄîThis ≈øentence is gone out of my mouth again≈øt you, MENE, MENE, TEKEL.
Thou art weighed in the ballances, and art found wanting.
God hath numbred thy Kingdome, and fini≈øhed it.
And thou, and all that joyne with thee, or are (in the lea≈øt degree) acce≈ø≈øary to thy former, or like intended pranks, ≈øhall mo≈øt terribly and mo≈øt ≈øtrangely be plagued.
2 There is a little ≈øparke lies under (that huge heap of a≈øhes) all thine honour, pomp, pride, wealth, and riches, which ≈øhall utterly con≈øume all that is uppermo≈øt, as it is written.

The Lord, the Lord of Ho≈øts, ≈øhall ≈øend among his fat ones, leanene≈ø≈øe; and under his glory he ≈øhall kindle a burning, like the burning of a fire, and the light of I≈ørael ≈øhall be for a fire, and his holy one for a flame, and it ≈øhall burne and devoure his thornes, and his briers in one day.

And ≈øhall con≈øume the glory of his Forre≈øt, and of his fruitfull field, both ≈øoule and body (i. e. this ≈øhall be done inwardly and outwardly, and ≈øhall be fulfilled both in the hi≈øtory and my≈øtery) and the re≈øt of the trees of his Forre≈øt ≈øhall be few, that a childe may write them.

And the Lord, the Lord of Hoa≈øts, ≈øhall lop the bough with terror, and the high ones of ≈øtature ≈øhall be hewen down, and the
haughty ≈øhall be humbled, And he ≈øhall cut down the thickets of the Forre≈øt with iron, and Lebanon ≈øhall fall by a mighty one, I≈øa. 10.
3 Behold, behold, I have told you.
Take it to heart, el≈øe you'l repent every veine of your heart.
For your own ≈øakes take heed.
Its my la≈øt warning.
For the cryes of the poore, for the oppre≈ø≈øion of the needy. For the horrid in≈øolency of proud man, who will dare to ≈øit in my throne, and judge unrighteous judgement.
Who will dare to touch mine Annoynted, and do my Prophets harme.
For the≈øe things ≈øake (now) am I arri≈øen, ≈øaith the Lord,

div.head: CHAP. V.
div.p: 1 O London, London, my bowels are rolled together (in me) for thee, and my compa≈ø≈øions within me, are kindled towards thee.

And now I onely tell thee, that it was not in vaine that this forme hath been brought ≈øo farre to thee, to proclaime the day of the Lord throughout thy ≈øtreets, day and night, for twelve or thirteen dayes together.
And that I have been made ≈øuch a ≈øigne, and a wonder before many of thine Inhabitants faces.

2 Many of them (among other ≈øtrange exploits) beholding me, fall down flat at the feet of creeples, beggers, lazars, ki≈ø≈øing their feet, and re≈øigning up my money to them; being ≈øeverall times over-emptied of money, that I have not had one penny left, and yet have recruited againe‚Äî
3 And now my hearts! you have been forwardly in all the appearances of God,
There is a ≈øtrange one (now on foot) judge it not, lea≈øt you be judged with a vengeance.
4 Turne not away your eyes from it, lea≈øt you (to your torment) heare this voyce‚ÄîI was a Stranger, and ye tooke me not in.

Well! bow down before Eternall Maje≈øty, who is univer≈øall love, bow down to equality, or free community, that no more of your blood be ≈øplit; that pride, arrogance, covetuou≈øne≈ø≈øe, malice, hypocri≈øie, ≈øelf ≈øeeking, &c. may live no longer. El≈øe I tremble at whats comming upon you.
Remember you have been warned with a witne≈ø≈øe.

div.head: CHAP. VI. A terrible word, and fatall blow from the Lord, upon the gathered Churches (≈øo called) e≈øpecially upon tho≈øe that are ≈øtiled Anabapti≈øts.
div.p: 1. HE that hath an eare to heare, let him hear what the Spirit ≈øaith again≈øt the Churches.

Thus ≈øaith the Lord: Woe be to thee The hou≈øe of vanity. Bethaven, who calle≈øt) thy ≈øelfe by the name The hou≈øe of God. Bethel, it ≈øhall be more tollerable (now in the day of judgement, for Tyre and Sydon, for tho≈øe whom thou accounte≈øt, and calle≈øt Heathens, then for thee.

2 And thou proud Lu ‚Ä¢ ifer, who exalte≈øt thy ≈øelf above all the Stars of God in heaven, ≈øhalt be brought down into hell; it ≈øhall be more tollerable for Sodom and Gomorrah, for drunkards and whoremongers, then for thee. Publicans and Harlots ≈øhall, Publicans and Harlots do ≈øooner enter into the Kingdome of heaven, then you.
I'le give thee this fatall blow, and leave thee.

3 Thou ha≈øt affronted, and defied the Almighty, more then the vile≈øt of men (upon the face of the earth) and that ≈øo much the more, by how much the more thou take≈øt upon thee the name of Saint, and a≈ø≈øume≈øt it to thy ≈øelf onely, damning all tho≈øe that are not of thy S ‚Ä¢ ct.

4 Wherefore be it knowne to all Tongues, Kinreds, Nations, and languages upon earth, That my mo≈øt Excellent Maje≈øty, the King of glory, the Eternall God, who dwelleth in the forme of the Writer of this Roll (among many other ≈øtrange and great exploits) hath i'th open ≈øtreets, with his hand fiercely ≈øtretcht out, his hat cockt up, his eyes ≈øet as if they would ≈øparkle out; and with
a mighty loud voyce charged 100. of Coaches, 100. of men and women of the greater ranke, and many notorious, deboi≈øt, ≈øwearing, roy≈øtering roaring Cavalliers (≈øo called) and other wilde ≈øparks of the Gentry: And have proclaimed the notable day of the Lord to them, and that through the ≈øtreets of the great Citie, and in Southwark; Many times great multitudes following him up and down, and this for the ≈øpace of 12. or 13. dayes: And yet (all this while) not one of them lifting up one finger, not touching one haire of his head, or laying one hand on his raiment.
But many, yea many notorious vile ones, in the e≈øteeme of men (yea of great quality among men) trembling and bowing to the God of heaven, &c.
But when I came to proclaim (al≈øo) the great day of the Lord (among you) O ye carnall Go≈øpellers.
The Devill (in you) roared out, who was tormented to ≈øome purpo≈øe, though not before his time.

He there ≈øhewed both his phangs and pawes, and would have torn me to pieces, and have eaten me up. Thy pride, envy, malice, arrogance, &c. was powred out like a river of Brim≈øtone, crying out, a Bla≈øphemer, a Bla≈øphemer, away with him: At length threatning me, and being at la≈øt raving mad, ≈øome tooke hold of my Cloak on one ≈øide, ≈øome on another, endeavouring to throw me from the place where I ≈øtood (to proclaime his Maje≈øties me≈ø≈øage) making a great uproar in a great congregation of people: Till at length I wrapt up my ≈øelf in ≈øilence (for a ≈øea≈øon) for the welfavour'd harlots confu≈øion, &c.
And to thine eternall ≈øhame and damnation (O mother of witchcrafts, who dwelle≈øt in gathered Churches) let this be told abroad: And let her FLESH be burnt with FIRE.
